subclusters.subcluster_name: Caloric Restriction and Metabolic Hormesis Theory

theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on mild stress inducing heat shock proteins and antioxidative enzymes in stem cells, emphasizing heat shock response as a key hormetic mechanism.
Describes mild heat stress activating heat shock transcription factors and proteasomal degradation, highlighting heat shock proteins in hormesis.
Details mild stress activating heat shock proteins and neurohormesis pathways, emphasizing protein chaperones and stress signaling in hormesis.
Describes hormetic phytochemicals activating vitagenes including heat shock proteins and sirtuins, focusing on endogenous defense pathways.
Explains geroprotectors acting through hormesis by inducing mild stress responses involving heat shock proteins and repair mechanisms.
Covers hormetins activating multiple stress response pathways including heat shock response, Nrf2, sirtuins, and autophagy, emphasizing integrated stress defenses.
Caloric restriction activates hormetic defense mechanisms including heat shock proteins and anti-inflammatory responses, fitting heat shock protein-mediated hormesis.
Mitochondrial stress induces neuronal hormesis involving stress response pathways and systemic aging regulation, linked to cellular stress responses.
Focuses on hormesis involving mitochondrial signaling, mitohormesis, antioxidant responses, and autophagy, highlighting mitochondrial ROS as central.
Describes hormesis driven by bile acid-induced mitochondrial remodeling and mitohormesis, linking mitochondrial function to longevity evolution.
Dietary restriction induces mitohormesis via mitochondrial ROS and nutrient sensing pathways, emphasizing mitochondrial role in hormetic lifespan extension.
Describes mitohormesis and xenohormesis with mitochondrial ROS as signaling molecules mediating hormetic adaptive responses to dietary restriction.
Focuses on mitohormesis and redox-sensitive signaling pathways (Nrf2, HSF1) activated by mild mitochondrial ROS to promote longevity.
Mild oxidative stress induces ROS signaling and upregulation of antioxidant enzymes, highlighting mitochondrial ROS in hormetic lifespan extension.
Exercise-induced ROS production triggers adaptive antioxidant and repair responses, consistent with mitochondrial ROS-driven hormesis.
Focuses on ROS, especially hydrogen peroxide, as hormetic triggers inducing antioxidant defenses and promoting longevity.
Describes adaptive responses to low-level oxidative stress including exercise-induced ROS signaling and mitochondrial biogenesis.
Neuronal mitochondrial adaptive responses to bioenergetic stress involve mitochondrial biogenesis, antioxidant defenses, and mitophagy.
